currentDoc:
Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---
In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---
In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---
In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---
In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---
In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W
hen it comes to high risk sports, the cathlete puts time and effort to train and hone their abilities, to meet with exceedingly high demands that are associated with those kind of sports

The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---
In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W
hen it comes to high risk sports, the cathlete puts time and effort to train and hone their abilities, to meet with exceedingly high demands that are associated with those kind of sports. Like other sports, the end results or reasons for why such people would do high risk sports deemed dangerous are primarily self-serving. It is often for

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W
hen it comes to high risk sports, the cathlete puts time and effort to train and hone their abilities, to meet with exceedingly high demands that are associated with those kind of sports. Like other sports, the end results or reasons for why such people would do high risk sports deemed dangerous are primarily self-serving. It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---
In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W
hen it comes to high risk sports, the cathlete puts time and effort to train and hone their abilities, to meet with exceedingly high demands that are associated with those kind of sports. Like other sports, the end results or reasons for why such people would do high risk sports deemed dangerous are primarily self-serving. It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W
hen it comes to high risk sports, the cathlete puts time and effort to train and hone their abilities, to meet with exceedingly high demands that are associated with those kind of sports. Like other sports, the end results or reasons for why such people would do high risk sports deemed dangerous are primarily self-serving. It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---
In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W
hen it comes to high risk sports, the cathlete puts time and effort to train and hone their abilities, to meet with exceedingly high demands that are associated with those kind of sports. Like other sports, the end results or reasons for why such people would do high risk sports deemed dangerous are primarily self-serving. It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Those people that do break the boundaries of the sports are often revered by many, who hear their achievements and see what c

Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W
hen it comes to high risk sports, the cathlete puts time and effort to train and hone their abilities, to meet with exceedingly high demands that are associated with those kind of sports. Like other sports, the end results or reasons for why such people would do high risk sports deemed dangerous are primarily self-serving. It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---
In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W
hen it comes to high risk sports, the cathlete puts time and effort to train and hone their abilities, to meet with exceedingly high demands that are associated with those kind of sports. Like other sports, the end results or reasons for why such people would do high risk sports deemed dangerous are primarily self-serving. It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Those people that do break the boundaries of the sports are often revered by many, who hear their achievements and see what can be achieved with effort and time. In that cases, pursuing those sports ha

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---
In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W
hen it comes to high risk sports, the cathlete puts time and effort to train and hone their abilities, to meet with exceedingly high demands that are associated with those kind of sports. Like other sports, the end results or reasons for why such people would do high risk sports deemed dangerous are primarily self-serving. It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Those people that do break the boundaries of the sports are often revered by many, who hear their achievements and see what can be achieved with effort and time. In that cases, pursuing those sports have indirect benefits tow

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---
In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W
hen it comes to high risk sports, the cathlete puts time and effort to train and hone their abilities, to meet with exceedingly high demands that are associated with those kind of sports. Like other sports, the end results or reasons for why such people would do high risk sports deemed dangerous are primarily self-serving. It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Those people that do break the boundaries of the sports are often revered by many, who hear their achievements and see what can be achieved with effort and time. In that cases, pursuing those sports have indirect benefits to others who hear of such aci

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---
In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W

The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W
hen it comes to high risk sports, the cathlete puts time and effort to train and hone their abilities, to meet with exceedingly high demands that are associated with those kind of sports. Like other sports, the end results or reasons for why such people would do high risk sports deemed dangerous are primarily self-serving. It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Those people that do break the boundaries of the sports are often revered by many, who hear their achievements and see what can be achieved with effort and time. In that cases, pursuing those sports have indirect benefits to others who hear of such achievements. Many can be inspired by tales of people who climb supposedly unclimbable mountains, or

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Those people that do break the boundaries of the sports are often revered by many, who hear their achievements and see what can be achieved with effort and time. In that cases, pursuing those sports have indirect benefits to others who hear of such achievements. Many can be inspired by tales of people who climb supposedly unclimbable mountains, or people who despite the ri

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---
In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W

It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Those people that do break the boundaries of the sports are often revered by many, who hear their achievements and see what can be achieved with effort and time. In that cases, pursuing those sports have indirect benefits to others who hear of such achievements. Many can be inspired by tales of people who climb supposedly unclimbable mountains, or people who despite the risk of some sports, were ab

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---
In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W

The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W
hen it comes to high risk sports, the cathlete puts time and effort to train and hone their abilities, to meet with exceedingly high demands that are associated with those kind of sports. Like other sports, the end results or reasons for why such people would do high risk sports deemed dangerous are primarily self-serving. It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Those people that do break the boundaries of the sports are often revered by many, who hear their achievements and see what can be achieved with effort and time. In that cases, pursuing those sports have indirect benefits to others who hear of such achievements. Many can be inspired by tales of people who climb supposedly unclimbable mountains, or people who despite the risk of some sports, were able to break world records

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---
In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W
hen it comes to high risk sports, the cathlete puts time and effort to train and hone their abilities, to meet with exceedingly high demands that are associated with those kind of sports. Like other sports, the end results or reasons for why such people would do high risk sports deemed dangerous are primarily self-serving. It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Those people that do break the boundaries of the sports are often revered by many, who hear their achievements and see what can be achieved with effort and time. In that cases, pursuing those sports have indirect benefits to others who hear of such achievements. Many can be inspired by tales of people who climb supposedly unscaleable mountains, or people who despite the risk of some sports, were able to break world records. Thus,

Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W
hen it comes to high risk sports, the cathlete puts time and effort to train and hone their abilities, to meet with exceedingly high demands that are associated with those kind of sports. Like other sports, the end results or reasons for why such people would do high risk sports deemed dangerous are primarily self-serving. It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Those people that do break the boundaries of the sports are often revered by many, who hear their achievements and see what can be achieved with effort and time. In that cases, pursuing those sports have indirect benefits to others who hear of such achievements. Many can be inspired by tales of people who climb supposedly unscaleable mountains, or people who despite the risk of some sports, were able to break world records. T

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---
In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W
hen it comes to high risk sports, the cathlete puts time and effort to train and hone their abilities, to meet with exceedingly high demands that are associated with those kind of sports. Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---
In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W
hen it comes to high risk sports, the cathlete puts time and effort to train and hone their abilities, to meet with exceedingly high demands that are associated with those kind of sports. Like other sports, the end results or reasons for why such people would do high risk sports deemed dangerous are primarily self-serving. It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Those people that do break the boundaries of the sports are often revered by many, who hear their achievements and see what can be achieved with effort and time. In that cases, pursuing those sports have indirect benefits to others who hear of such achievements. Many can be inspired by tales of people who climb supposedly unscaleable mountains, or people who despite the risk of some sports, were able to break world records. Pursuing those sports are a conscious actio

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---
In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W
hen it comes to high risk sports, the cathlete puts time and effort to train and hone their abilities, to meet with exceedingly high demands that are associated with those kind of sports. Like other sports, the end results or reasons for why such people would do high risk sports deemed dangerous are primarily self-serving. It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Those people that do break the boundaries of the sports are often revered by many, who hear their achievements and see what can be achieved with effort and time. In that cases, pursuing those sports have indirect benefits to others who hear of such achievements. Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---
In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---
In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W
hen it comes to high risk sports, the cathlete puts time and effort to train and hone their abilities, to meet with exceedingly high demands that are associated with those kind of sports. Like other sports, the end results or reasons for why such people would do high risk sports deemed dangerous are primarily self-serving. It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Those people that do break the boundaries of the sports are often revered by many, who hear their achievements and see what can be achieved with effort and time. In that cases, pursuing those sports have indirect benefits to others who hear of such achievements. Many can be inspired by tales of people who climb supposedly unscaleable mountains, or people who despite the risk of some sports, were able to break world records. Pursuing those sports are a conscious action people take, who are often well aware of the stakes and dag

The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W
hen it comes to high risk sports, the cathlete puts time and effort to train and hone their abilities, to meet with exceedingly high demands that are associated with those kind of sports. Like other sports, the end results or reasons for why such people would do high risk sports deemed dangerous are primarily self-serving. It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Those people that do break the boundaries of the sports are often revered by many, who hear their achievements and see what can be achieved with effort and time. In that cases, pursuing those sports have indirect benefits to others who hear of such achievements. Many can be inspired by tales of people who climb supposedly unscaleable mountains, or people who despite the risk of some sports, were able to break world records. Pursuing those sports are a conscious action people take, who are often well aware of the stakes and dangers found in the sport.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---
In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W
hen it comes to high risk sports, the cathlete puts time and effort to train and hone their abilities, to meet with exceedingly high demands that are associated with those kind of sports. Like other sports, the end results or reasons for why such people would do high risk sports deemed dangerous are primarily self-serving. It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Those people that do break the boundaries of the sports are often revered by many, who hear their achievements and see what can be achieved with effort and time. In that cases, pursuing those sports have indirect benefits to others who hear of such achievements. Many can be inspired by tales of people who climb supposedly unscaleable mountains, or people who despite the risk of some sports, were able to break world records. Pursuing those sports are a conscious action people take, who are often well aware of the stakes and dangers found in the sport.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---
In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W
hen it comes to high risk sports, the cathlete puts time and effort to train and hone their abilities, to meet with exceedingly high demands that are associated with those kind of sports. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---
In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W
hen it comes to high risk sports, the cathlete puts time and effort to train and hone their abilities, to meet with exceedingly high demands that are associated with those kind of sports. Like other sports, the end results or reasons for why such people would do high risk sports deemed dangerous are primarily self-serving. It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Those people that do break the boundaries of the sports are often revered by many, who hear their achievements and see what can be achieved with effort and time. In that cases, pursuing those sports have indirect benefits to others who hear of such achievements. Many can be inspired by tales of people who climb supposedly unscaleable mountains, or people who despite the risk of some sports, were able to break world records. Pursuing those sports are a conscious action people take, who are often well aware of the stakes and dangers found in the sport.

In terms of what a person finds is too dangerous to pursue, that lies in the person and how th

In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W
hen it comes to high risk sports, the cathlete puts time and effort to train and hone their abilities, to meet with exceedingly high demands that are associated with those kind of sports. Like other sports, the end results or reasons for why such people would do high risk sports deemed dangerous are primarily self-serving. It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Those people that do break the boundaries of the sports are often revered by many, who hear their achievements and see what can be achieved with effort and time. In that cases, pursuing those sports have indirect benefits to others who hear of such achievements. Many can be inspired by tales of people who climb supposedly unscaleable mountains, or people who despite the risk of some sports, were able to break world records. Pursuing those sports are a conscious action people take, who are often well aware of the stakes and dangers found in the sport.

In terms of what a person finds is too dangerous to pursue, that lies in the person and how they perceive sa

Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W
hen it comes to high risk sports, the cathlete puts time and effort to train and hone their abilities, to meet with exceedingly high demands that are associated with those kind of sports. Like other sports, the end results or reasons for why such people would do high risk sports deemed dangerous are primarily self-serving. It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Those people that do break the boundaries of the sports are often revered by many, who hear their achievements and see what can be achieved with effort and time. In that cases, pursuing those sports have indirect benefits to others who hear of such achievements. Many can be inspired by tales of people who climb supposedly unscaleable mountains, or people who despite the risk of some sports, were able to break world records. Pursuing those sports are a conscious action people take, who are often well aware of the stakes and dangers found in the sport.

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---
In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W
hen it comes to high risk sports, the cathlete puts time and effort to train and hone their abilities, to meet with exceedingly high demands that are associated with those kind of sports. Like other sports, the end results or reasons for why such people would do high risk sports deemed dangerous are primarily self-serving. It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Those people that do break the boundaries of the sports are often revered by many, who hear their achievements and see what can be achieved with effort and time. In that cases, pursuing those sports have indirect benefits to others who hear of such achievements. Many can be inspired by tales of people who climb supposedly unscaleable mountains, or people who despite the risk of some sports, were able to break world records. Pursuing those sports are a conscious action people take, who are often well aware of the stakes and dangers found in the sport.

In terms of what a person finds is too dangerous to pursue, that lies in the person and how they perceive said sport. Some might perceive mountain climbing as being too dangerous and decline to even attempt it, while others will put in all of the effort, spending years getting better at it, to accomplish

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---
In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W
hen it comes to high risk sports, the cathlete puts time and effort to train and hone their abilities, to meet with exceedingly high demands that are associated with those kind of sports. Like other sports, the end results or reasons for why such people would do high risk sports deemed dangerous are primarily self-serving. It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Those people that do break the boundaries of the sports are often revered by many, who hear their achievements and see what can be achieved with effort and time. In that cases, pursuing those sports have indirect benefits to others who hear of such achievements. Many can be inspired by tales of people who climb supposedly unscaleable mountains, or people who despite the risk of some sports, were able to break world records. Pursuing those sports are a conscious action people take, who are often well aware of the stakes and dangers found in the sport.

In terms of what a person finds is too dangerous to pursue, that lies in the person and how they perceive said sport. Some might perceive mountain climbing as being too dangerous and decline to even attempt it, while others will put in all of the effort, spending years getting better at it, to accomplish feats and impressive displays of prows

It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Those people that do break the boundaries of the sports are often revered by many, who hear their achievements and see what can be achieved with effort and time. In that cases, pursuing those sports have indirect benefits to others who hear of such achievements. Many can be inspired by tales of people who climb supposedly unscaleable mountains, or people who despite the risk of some sports, were able to break world records. Pursuing those sports are a conscious action people take, who are often well aware of the stakes and dangers found in the sport.

In terms of what a person finds is too dangerous to pursue, that lies in the person and how they perceive said sport. Some might perceive mountain climbing as being too dangerous and decline to even attempt it, while others will put in all of the effort, spending years getting better at it, to accomplish feats and impressive displays of prowess. Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---
In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Those people that do break the boundaries of the sports are often revered by many, who hear their achievements and see what can be achieved with effort and time. In that cases, pursuing those sports have indirect benefits to others who hear of such achievements. Many can be inspired by tales of people who climb supposedly unscaleable mountains, or people who despite the risk of some sports, were able to break world records. Pursuing those sports are a conscious action people take, who are often well aware of the stakes and dangers found in the sport.

In terms of what a person finds is too dangerous to pursue, that lies in the person and how they perceive said sport. Some might perceive mountain climbing as being too dangerous and decline to even attempt it, while others will put in all of the effort, spending years getting better at it, to accomplish feats and impressive displays of prowess. Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---
In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W

Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---
In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W
hen it comes to high risk sports, the cathlete puts time and effort to train and hone their abilities, to meet with exceedingly high demands that are associated with those kind of sports. Like other sports, the end results or reasons for why such people would do high risk sports deemed dangerous are primarily self-serving. It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Those people that do break the boundaries of the sports are often revered by many, who hear their achievements and see what can be achieved with effort and time. In that cases, pursuing those sports have indirect benefits to others who hear of such achievements. Many can be inspired by tales of people who climb supposedly unscaleable mountains, or people who despite the risk of some sports, were able to break world records. Pursuing those sports are a conscious action people take, who are often well aware of the stakes and dangers found in the sport.

In terms of what a person finds is too dangerous to pursue, that lies in the person and how they perceive said sport. Some might perceive mountain climbing as being too dangerous and decline to even attempt it, while others will put in all of the effort, spending years getting better at it, to accomplish feats and impressive displays of prowess. What a person deems is dangerous, might be doable to another person. Thus I doubt th

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---
In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W
hen it comes to high risk sports, the cathlete puts time and effort to train and hone their abilities, to meet with exceedingly high demands that are associated with those kind of sports. Like other sports, the end results or reasons for why such people would do high risk sports deemed dangerous are primarily self-serving. It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Those people that do break the boundaries of the sports are often revered by many, who hear their achievements and see what can be achieved with effort and time. In that cases, pursuing those sports have indirect benefits to others who hear of such achievements. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W
hen it comes to high risk sports, the cathlete puts time and effort to train and hone their abilities, to meet with exceedingly high demands that are associated with those kind of sports. Like other sports, the end results or reasons for why such people would do high risk sports deemed dangerous are primarily self-serving. It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Those people that do break the boundaries of the sports are often revered by many, who hear their achievements and see what can be achieved with effort and time. In that cases, pursuing those sports have indirect benefits to others who hear of such achievements. Many can be inspired by tales of people who climb supposedly unscaleable mountains, or people who despite the risk of some sports, were able to break world records. Pursuing those sports are a conscious action people take, who are often well aware of the stakes and dangers found in the sport.

In terms of what a person finds is too dangerous to pursue, that lies in the person and how they perceive said sport. Some might perceive mountain climbing as being too dangerous and decline to even attempt it, while others will put in all of the effort, spending years getting better at it, to accomplish feats and impressive displays of prowess. What a person deems is dangerous, might be doable to another person. Thus I doubt that there will be a sport that ei

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---
In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W
hen it comes to high risk sports, the cathlete puts time and effort to train and hone their abilities, to meet with exceedingly high demands that are associated with those kind of sports. Like other sports, the end results or reasons for why such people would do high risk sports deemed dangerous are primarily self-serving. It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Those people that do break the boundaries of the sports are often revered by many, who hear their achievements and see what can be achieved with effort and time. In that cases, pursuing those sports have indirect benefits to others who hear of such achievements. Many can be inspired by tales of people who climb supposedly unscaleable mountains, or people who despite the risk of some sports, were able to break world records. Pursuing those sports are a conscious action people take, who are often well aware of the stakes and dangers found in the sport.

In terms of what a person finds is too dangerous to pursue, that lies in the person and how they perceive said sport. Some might perceive mountain climbing as being too dangerous and decline to even attempt it, while others will put in all of the effort, spending years getting better at it, to accomplish feats and impressive displays of prowess. What a person deems is dangerous, might be doable to another person. Thus I doubt that there will be a sport that exists in the world that would be cons

Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W
hen it comes to high risk sports, the cathlete puts time and effort to train and hone their abilities, to meet with exceedingly high demands that are associated with those kind of sports. Like other sports, the end results or reasons for why such people would do high risk sports deemed dangerous are primarily self-serving. It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Those people that do break the boundaries of the sports are often revered by many, who hear their achievements and see what can be achieved with effort and time. In that cases, pursuing those sports have indirect benefits to others who hear of such achievements. Many can be inspired by tales of people who climb supposedly unscaleable mountains, or people who despite the risk of some sports, were able to break world records. Pursuing those sports are a conscious action people take, who are often well aware of the stakes and dangers found in the sport.

In terms of what a person finds is too dangerous to pursue, that lies in the person and how they perceive said sport. Some might perceive mountain climbing as being too dangerous and decline to even attempt it, while others will put in all of the effort, spending years getting better at it, to accomplish feats and impressive displays of prowess. What a person deems is dangerous, might be doable to another person. Thus I doubt that there will be a sport that exists in the world that would be considered by all as to

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W
hen it comes to high risk sports, the cathlete puts time and effort to train and hone their abilities, to meet with exceedingly high demands that are associated with those kind of sports. Like other sports, the end results or reasons for why such people would do high risk sports deemed dangerous are primarily self-serving. It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Those people that do break the boundaries of the sports are often revered by many, who hear their achievements and see what can be achieved with effort and time. In that cases, pursuing those sports have indirect benefits to others who hear of such achievements. Many can be inspired by tales of people who climb supposedly unscaleable mountains, or people who despite the risk of some sports, were able to break world records. Pursuing those sports are a conscious action people take, who are often well aware of the stakes and dangers found in the sport.

In terms of what a person finds is too dangerous to pursue, that lies in the person and how they perceive said sport. Some might perceive mountain climbing as being too dangerous and decline to even attempt it, while others will put in all of the effort, spending years getting better at it, to accomplish feats and impressive displays of prowess. What a person deems is dangerous, might be doable to another person. Thus I doubt that there will be a sport that exists in the world that would be considered by all as too dangerous to do, especially since high risk sports have been around for so long, with people always finding a way to up the ante of the sport. The

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Like other sports, the end results or reasons for why such people would do high risk sports deemed dangerous are primarily self-serving. It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Those people that do break the boundaries of the sports are often revered by many, who hear their achievements and see what can be achieved with effort and time. In that cases, pursuing those sports have indirect benefits to others who hear of such achievements. Many can be inspired by tales of people who climb supposedly unscaleable mountains, or people who despite the risk of some sports, were able to break world records. Pursuing those sports are a conscious action people take, who are often well aware of the stakes and dangers found in the sport.

In terms of what a person finds is too dangerous to pursue, that lies in the person and how they perceive said sport. Some might perceive mountain climbing as being too dangerous and decline to even attempt it, while others will put in all of the effort, spending years getting better at it, to accomplish feats and impressive displays of prowess. What a person deems is dangerous, might be doable to another person. Thus I doubt that there will be a sport that exists in the world that would be considered by all as too dangerous to do, especially since high risk sports have been around for so long, with people always finding a way to up the ante of the sport. It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Those people that do break the boundaries of the sports are often revered by many, who hear their achievements and see what can be achieved with effort and time. In that cases, pursuing those sports have indirect benefits to others who hear of such achievements. Many can be inspired by tales of people who climb supposedly unscaleable mountains, or people who despite the risk of some sports, were able to break world records. Pursuing those sports are a conscious action people take, who are often well aware of the stakes and dangers found in the sport.

In terms of what a person finds is too dangerous to pursue, that lies in the person and how they perceive said sport. Some might perceive mountain climbing as being too dangerous and decline to even attempt it, while others will put in all of the effort, spending years getting better at it, to accomplish feats and impressive displays of prowess. What a person deems is dangerous, might be doable to another person. Thus I doubt that there will be a sport that exists in the world that would be considered by all as too dangerous to do, especially since high risk sports have been around for so long, with people always finding a way to up the ante of the sport. The important thing to note is that th

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---
In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W

It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Those people that do break the boundaries of the sports are often revered by many, who hear their achievements and see what can be achieved with effort and time. In that cases, pursuing those sports have indirect benefits to others who hear of such achievements. Many can be inspired by tales of people who climb supposedly unscaleable mountains, or people who despite the risk of some sports, were able to break world records. Pursuing those sports are a conscious action people take, who are often well aware of the stakes and dangers found in the sport.

In terms of what a person finds is too dangerous to pursue, that lies in the person and how they perceive said sport. Some might perceive mountain climbing as being too dangerous and decline to even attempt it, while others will put in all of the effort, spending years getting better at it, to accomplish feats and impressive displays of prowess. What a person deems is dangerous, might be doable to another person. Thus I doubt that there will be a sport that exists in the world that would be considered by all as too dangerous to do, especially since high risk sports have been around for so long, with people always finding a way to up the ante of the sport. The important thing to note is that the athletes and pa

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---
In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W

Like other sports, the end results or reasons for why such people would do high risk sports deemed dangerous are primarily self-serving. It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Those people that do break the boundaries of the sports are often revered by many, who hear their achievements and see what can be achieved with effort and time. In that cases, pursuing those sports have indirect benefits to others who hear of such achievements. Many can be inspired by tales of people who climb supposedly unscaleable mountains, or people who despite the risk of some sports, were able to break world records. Pursuing those sports are a conscious action people take, who are often well aware of the stakes and dangers found in the sport.

In terms of what a person finds is too dangerous to pursue, that lies in the person and how they perceive said sport. Some might perceive mountain climbing as being too dangerous and decline to even attempt it, while others will put in all of the effort, spending years getting better at it, to accomplish feats and impressive displays of prowess. What a person deems is dangerous, might be doable to another person. Thus I doubt that there will be a sport that exists in the world that would be considered by all as too dangerous to do, especially since high risk sports have been around for so long, with people always finding a way to up the ante of the sport. The important thing to note is that the athletes and participants of hi

Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W
hen it comes to high risk sports, the cathlete puts time and effort to train and hone their abilities, to meet with exceedingly high demands that are associated with those kind of sports. Like other sports, the end results or reasons for why such people would do high risk sports deemed dangerous are primarily self-serving. It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Those people that do break the boundaries of the sports are often revered by many, who hear their achievements and see what can be achieved with effort and time. In that cases, pursuing those sports have indirect benefits to others who hear of such achievements. Many can be inspired by tales of people who climb supposedly unscaleable mountains, or people who despite the risk of some sports, were able to break world records. Pursuing those sports are a conscious action people take, who are often well aware of the stakes and dangers found in the sport.

In terms of what a person finds is too dangerous to pursue, that lies in the person and how they perceive said sport. Some might perceive mountain climbing as being too dangerous and decline to even attempt it, while others will put in all of the effort, spending years getting better at it, to accomplish feats and impressive displays of prowess. What a person deems is dangerous, might be doable to another person. Thus I doubt that there will be a sport that exists in the world that would be considered by all as too dangerous to do, especially since high risk sports have been around for so long, with people always finding a way to up the ante of the sport. The important thing to note is that the athletes and participants of high risk sports ar

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---
In some ways, many if not all sports are selfish to pursue. The pursuit of any sport requires dedication, patience and often sacrifice to achieve one's goals, which includes prestige and reputation. The top athletes are revered by many, but their actions do not necessarily benefit others directly. Rather, many athletes serve as sources of inspiration, to motivate others to achieve their goals and overcoming obstacles, even if it isn't regarding the same sport or activity. W
hen it comes to high risk sports, the cathlete puts time and effort to train and hone their abilities, to meet with exceedingly high demands that are associated with those kind of sports. Like other sports, the end results or reasons for why such people would do high risk sports deemed dangerous are primarily self-serving. It is often for fame and prestige, while some do it to prove themselves that they can. It is often about pushing the limits of what is possible, and leaving behind a legacy. Those people that do break the boundaries of the sports are often revered by many, who hear their achievements and see what can be achieved with effort and time. In that cases, pursuing those sports have indirect benefits to others who hear of such achievements. Many can be inspired by tales of people who climb supposedly unscaleable mountains, or people who despite the risk of some sports, were able to break world records. Pursuing those sports are a conscious action people take, who are often well aware of the stakes and dangers found in the sport.

In terms of what a person finds is too dangerous to pursue, that lies in the person and how they perceive said sport. Some might perceive mountain climbing as being too dangerous and decline to even attempt it, while others will put in all of the effort, spending years getting better at it, to accomplish feats and impressive displays of prowess. What a person deems is dangerous, might be doable to another person. Thus I doubt that there will be a sport that exists in the world that would be considered by all as too dangerous to do, especially since high risk sports have been around for so long, with people always finding a way to up the ante of the sport. The important thing to note is that the athletes and participants of high risk sports are aware of the dan
